questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought in for a syncopal episode. He started on lisinopril for his HTN today. On arrival, he is fully oriented. His pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Concurrent treatment with which of the following agents most likely predisposed the patient to this episode?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients on thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide have reduced intravascular volume from enhanced renal sodium and water excretion, making them particularly susceptible to first-dose hypotension when an ACE inhibitor is added.

Lisinopril causes vasodilation and decreases angiotensin II-mediated sodium retention; in a volume-depleted patient, this synergism can precipitate a pronounced blood pressure drop.

First-dose hypotension is a well-recognised adverse effect of ACE inhibitors, especially when initiated in patients taking diuretics or who are hypovolemic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lithium (Option B): ACE inhibitors can reduce lithium clearance, risking toxicity, but lithium does not directly potentiate hypotension.

TMP-SMX (Option C): Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can elevate potassium but has no synergistic hypotensive effect with ACE inhibitors.

Metformin (Option D): Metformin does not affect blood pressure regulation and would not predispose to ACE inhibitor-induced hypotension.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman develops a loss of hearing after getting admitted for acute decompensated heart failure. The responsible offending agent most likely acts on which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given the acute onset of symptoms (here, hearing loss) shortly after initiating treatment, an adverse medication effect should be suspected. This patient was most likely previously treated with intravenous furosemide, a loop diuretic used to treat acute decompensated heart failure that (like all loop diuretics) acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl--cotransporters on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

Other important adverse effects of loop diuretics include metabolic abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, metabolic alkalosis), dehydration, and sulfonamide hypersensitivity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proximal convoluted tubule (Option A): Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act here and are not associated with ototoxicity.

Distal convoluted tubule (Option B): Thiazide diuretics target this segment, causing hypokalemia but not hearing loss.

Collecting duct (Option D): Potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone) work here and do not produce ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a severe headache and vomiting that started after she was hiking in the mountains at high altitude. Therapy is initiated with a drug that alkalinizes the urine. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of this drug in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetazolamide, the treatment of choice for acute mountain sickness, is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts in the proximal convoluted tubule to block bicarbonate reabsorption.

Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase decreases H+ secretion and HCO3- reabsorption, resulting in bicarbonate diuresis and urine alkalinization.

The resultant normal anion-gap metabolic acidosis stimulates respiratory drive (hyperventilation), thereby increasing blood O2 and decreasing CO2 to aid acclimatisation at high altitude.

Explanation of Other Options:

Thick ascending limb (Option B): Loop diuretics act here on the Na-K-2Cl- cotransporter but do not alkalinise urine or produce metabolic acidosis.

Distal convoluted tubule (Option C): Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- cotransporter in this segment; they reduce Ca2+ excretion but have minimal effect on bicarbonate.

Collecting duct (Option D): Potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone, amiloride) act here on aldosterone receptors or ENaC channels, neither of which significantly alters urine pH.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with congestive heart failure comes to you for a follow-up examination. Physical examination shows bilateral, mildly tender enlargement of breast tissue. This patient's physical examination finding is most likely caused by a drug that acts at which of the following sites in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gynecomastia is a classic side effect of spironolactone, which is used in the management of congestive heart failure.
  • Spironolactone, which is a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist, acts on the principal cells in the cortical collecting ducts. It is used to reduce morbidity and mortality in patients with heart failure.
  • Spironolactone inhibits the binding of androgens to their receptors as well as the activity of enzymes involved in androgen synthesis (e.g., 17, 20-desmolase, 17α-hydroxylase). It also increases the peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol and displaces estradiol from SHBG. This combination of antiandrogenic and pro-estrogenic effects can cause painful gynecomastia and impotence in men.
  • Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist with a greater specificity for the mineralocorticoid receptor than spironolactone; it has a lower incidence of endocrine side effects.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department, where her temperature is 99.1°F, pulse is 182/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. An ECG shows ventricular tachycardia. She was diagnosed with alcoholic liver cirrhosis 2 years ago. Examination shows a protruding, distended abdomen that is dull to percussion with a positive fluid wave. Which of the following treatments is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
Initial laboratory studies show:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient received medical therapy for ascites (indicated by her clinical findings and history of cirrhosis). Furosemide was likely prescribed to this patient to treat her ascites. If administered in excess, furosemide can lead to a profound diuresis with water and electrolyte depletion, resulting in hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hyponatremia,and ultimately the acute kidney injury and metabolic alkalosis as seen in this patient.
  • Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia can cause life-threatening arrhythmias, such as the ventricular tachycardia suffered by this patient. In addition to correcting this patient's electrolyte levels, management would also include prompt rehydration with intravenous fluids.The drug responsible for her laboratory findings can also cause hyperglycemia and ototoxicity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): A proximal tubule carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for glaucoma and altitude sickness; causes bicarbonate diuresis and metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis, and is not indicated for ascites.

Spironolactone (Option B): A potassium-sparing diuretic first-line for cirrhotic ascites; excess use produces hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis, the opposite of this patient's hypokalemic, alkalotic state.

Mannitol (Option D): An osmotic diuretic for cerebral edema or acute glaucoma; not used for ascites and causes water diuresis with no metabolic alkalosis, instead it can worsen volume status and perhaps cause metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman is presented with a severe headache, nausea and vomiting. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Treatment with an intravenous drug is initiated, and the patient's urine output subsequently increases. The patient is at greatest risk of which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with nausea, vomiting and headache. Examination shows the Cushing triad (bradycardia, respiratory depression, and hypertension).

These are classic features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), which can be treated with mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

It causes an increase in plasma osmolality, resulting in osmotic shifts of water into the intravascular space. This effect decreases cerebral oedema but can lead to iatrogenic volume overload and pulmonary oedema.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tinnitus (Option A): A hallmark of loop diuretic-induced ototoxicity (e.g., furosemide), not seen with mannitol.

DRESS (Option C): A severe drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms linked to anticonvulsants or antibiotics, unrelated to osmotic diuretics.

Hypercalcemia (Option D): Occurs with thiazide diuretics due to reduced renal calcium excretion, the opposite effect of mannitol.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. His blood pressure today is 160/90 mm Hg. The ECG are shown.The addition of which of the following drugs is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with clinical and ECG features suggestive of hypokalemia, a known adverse effect of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Eplerenone, a selective aldosterone receptor antagonist (SARA), acts on the collecting duct to reduce potassium excretion, counteracting the hypokalemic effects of thiazides.
  • It is especially useful in resistant hypertension and in patients already on potassium-wasting diuretics, making it the most suitable adjunct in this scenario.

Explanation of Other Options:

Furosemide (Option A): Loop diuretic; also causes hypokalemia and would exacerbate thiazide-induced potassium loss.

Hydralazine (Option B): Direct vasodilator; does not influence potassium levels and would not prevent thiazide-induced hypokalemia.

Mannitol (Option D): Osmotic diuretic; not used for hypertension and does not correct or cause significant hypokalemia.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman consumed a drug that inhibits Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule in excess. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Inhibition of Na+-Cl-cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics, which are used to treat hypertension, a common comorbidity in elderly patients.
  • Inhibition of Na+-Cl-cotransporters in the early DCT can cause hyponatremia due to increased Na+ Inhibition of Na+ reabsorption by the early DCT also increases Na+ delivery to the late DCT and early collecting tubule, which can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis due to increased K+ and H+ secretion in exchange for luminal Na+ reabsorption. It also causes hypercalcemia due in part to increased Ca2+ reabsorption at the proximal tubule as a result of increased extracellular fluid reabsorption in this segment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A: Loop diuretics can lead to hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. They increase luminal Na+ in the late DCT/collecting duct, promoting H+ and K+ secretion, raising pH.

Option C: Osmotic diuretics (e.g., mannitol) increase plasma osmolality, pulling water extracellularly. This causes dilutional hyponatremia, hypocalcemia, and metabolic acidosis. Cell shrinkage causes K+ efflux, leading to hyperkalemia.

Option D: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) cause bicarbonate loss, leading to metabolic acidosis, hyponatremia, and hypokalemia due to Na+-linked HCO3- excretion and distal Na+-K+ exchange.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath, lower extremity oedema, and a 4-kg weight gain. She has ischemic cardiomyopathy and rheumatoid arthritis. Therapy is initiated with intravenous furosemide. After 2 hours, urine output is minimal. Concomitant treatment with which of the following drugs is most likely to have contributed to treatment failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter in the thick ascending limb and enhances diuresis partly by stimulating renal prostaglandin E2 release, which dilates afferent arterioles and improves renal perfusion.
  • NSAIDs like diclofenac inhibit prostaglandin synthesis via COX inhibition, blunting this vasodilatory response and reducing glomerular filtration, leading to diuretic resistance.
  • In patients with volume overload or reduced renal perfusion (e.g., CHF), this NSAID-induced antagonism of furosemide action can be clinically significant and impair response.

Explanation of Other Options:

Digoxin (Option A): Furosemide and digoxin are frequently co-administered in ischemic cardiomyopathy. Loop diuretics like furosemide may cause hypokalemia, enhancing digoxin's binding to myocardial Na+/K+-ATPase and raising the risk of digoxin toxicity (e.g., arrhythmias). However, digoxin does not reduce urine output or interfere with diuretic efficacy, making it an unlikely cause for diuretic resistance.

Prednisolone (Option C): Prednisolone, due to its mineralocorticoid activity, increases sodium reabsorption and promotes potassium/hydrogen excretion in renal tubules, potentially worsening loop diuretic-induced hypokalemia. This increases the risk of metabolic disturbances, but not diuretic failure. It does not inhibit prostaglandins or reduce urine output.

Infliximab (Option D): Infliximab is a TNF-α inhibitor used in rheumatoid arthritis. It does not alter renal prostaglandin synthesis or interact with furosemide action. It may increase infection risk, including TB reactivation, but has no known impact on diuretic efficacy or urine output.

choices.text: Amiloride for edema associated with aldosteronism
Furosemide for severe hypertension and heart failure

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complains of paresthesias and occasional nausea associated with one of the drugs she is taking. She is found to have hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. She is probably taking
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces HCO3- reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to urinary bicarbonate loss and a hyperchloremic (normal anion gap) metabolic acidosis.

Chronic use is associated with paresthesias and gastrointestinal upset (e.g., nausea), especially in long-term treatments such as glaucoma.

This metabolic disturbance and neurologic symptoms are classic clues pointing toward acetazolamide toxicity or side effects.

Explanation of Other Options:

Amiloride (Option B): A potassium-sparing diuretic that typically causes hyperkalemia and does not lead to metabolic acidosis or paresthesias.

Furosemide (Option C): A loop diuretic that causes metabolic alkalosis due to increased H+ and K+ loss, not acidosis; ototoxicity, not paresthesias, is a notable side effect.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option D): Causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis; paresthesias and metabolic acidosis are not seen.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics would be most useful in the acute treatment of a comatose patient with traumatic brain injury and cerebral oedema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that increases plasma osmolality, drawing fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space, including brain tissue, thereby reducing cerebral oedema and intracranial pressure.
  • It is the first-line agent in acute neurologic emergencies such as traumatic brain injury with cerebral oedema due to its rapid onset and ability to reduce intracranial pressure effectively.
  • Common adverse effects include volume expansion → hyponatremia/pulmonary oedema initially, followed by excessive diuresis → hypernatremia and hypovolemia.

Stepwise increased ICP management

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in glaucoma or altitude sickness; does not reduce cerebral oedema effectively.

Chlorthalidone (Option C): A thiazide-like diuretic, useful in chronic hypertension but ineffective for acute reduction of intracranial pressure.

Furosemide (Option D): A loop diuretic with some role in cerebral edema adjunctively, but slower and less effective than mannitol in acute management.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man has a history of frequent episodes of renal colic with calcium-containing renal stones. A careful workup indicates that he has a defect in proximal tubular calcium reabsorption, which results in high concentrations of calcium salts in the tubular urine. The most useful diuretic agent in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that decreases calcium excretion in the urine by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • This calcium-sparing effect helps prevent calcium-containing kidney stones, especially in patients with idiopathic hypercalciuria.
  • It is considered the drug of choice for patients with recurrent calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis due to its ability to correct hypercalciuria.

Explanation of Other Options:

Furosemide (Option B): Loop diuretics increase urinary calcium excretion and can exacerbate renal colic due to calcium stone formation.

Diazoxide (Option C): A thiazide-like vasodilator used in hypertension and insulinoma, but it has no diuretic action and may cause sodium retention; it doesn't help in stone prevention.

Spironolactone (Option D): Although it has diuretic activity, it does not reduce calcium excretion. It may cause endocrine side effects like gynecomastia, and has no role in preventing renal stone formation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with "fainting spell", her blood pressure is 120/60 when lying down and 60/20 when she sits up. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her fainting spell?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Furosemide is a potent loop diuretic that can cause significant volume depletion, leading to orthostatic hypotension, especially in elderly patients.

In this case, the large drop in systolic and diastolic pressures upon sitting is characteristic of postural hypotension, often due to over-diuresis.

Additionally, furosemide-induced hypokalemia can predispose to arrhythmias, which may also contribute to fainting spells in susceptible individuals.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): Causes mild diuresis and metabolic acidosis, but it is less likely to cause significant volume depletion and postural hypotension.

Amiloride (Option B): A potassium-sparing diuretic with mild natriuretic effect; unlikely to cause orthostatic hypotension or significant volume depletion.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option D): Though it causes potassium loss, it rarely leads to volume depletion sufficient to cause orthostatic hypotension, especially at usual doses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung cancer has abnormally low serum osmolality and hyponatremia. A drug that increases the formation of dilute urine and is used to treat SIADH is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) causes water retention, leading to euvolemic hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inability to excrete dilute urine.
  • Tolvaptan is a selective oral vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that increases free water clearance (aquaresis), corrects serum sodium levels, and is indicated for the treatment of clinically significant hyponatremia.
  • Vaptans block the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) at renal collecting ducts. They are classified based on their route and receptor specificity:
    • IV: Conivaptan (blocks both V1 and V2 receptors)
    • Oral: Tolvaptan (selective V2 receptor blocker)
    • V1 antagonist: Relcovaptan

Explanation of Other Options:

Amiloride (Option A): Potassium-sparing diuretic; may be used in lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, but is not effective in SIADH.

Desmopressin (Option B): A synthetic ADH analogue; would worsen SIADH by enhancing water reabsorption.

Mannitol (Option C): Osmotic diuretic; increases urine output but does not counteract ADH effects or correct serum sodium.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old girl with a history of major depression and bulimia is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. She claims to have ingested several pills. She has also been very thirsty. Her temperature is 98°F, blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination shows dry oral mucosa and reduced skin turgor.
Laboratory results are as follows:
Which of the following medications did this patient most likely ingest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As per the given clinical scenario, the patient has consumed a diuretic, which can cause hyponatremia, hypokalemia and hypercalcemia. Thiazide diuretics match the given description.
  • Loop diuretics function by inhibiting the absorption of solutes within the thick ascending limb of Henle's loop, a process that is critical for maintenance of the corticomedullary concentration gradient. As a result, patients on loop diuretics are unable to maximally concentrate their urine and thus lose substantial amounts of both salt and water in the urine. In contrast, patients taking thiazides have a normal corticomedullary concentration gradient and are better able to retain free water in response to increased vasopressin levels. Thus, patients taking thiazide diuretics are more likely to retain free water and develop hyponatremia.
  • Thiazide diuretics can also lead to hypercalcemia secondary to increased proximal and distal tubule Ca++ reabsorption.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): Causes metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia, but typically does not cause hypercalcemia or significant hyponatremia.

Furosemide (Option B): Loop diuretic; causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Also leads to volume depletion, hyponatremia, and hypokalemia, but is not consistent with the full electrolyte profile in this case.

Spironolactone (Option D): Potassium-sparing diuretic; causes hyperkalemia and hyponatremia, but not hypokalemia or hypercalcemia as seen here.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): Induces natriuresis by inhibiting bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis or hypercalcemia. Also, it is not associated with significant electrolyte disturbances like those seen in this patient.

Furosemide (Option B): Inhibits Ca2+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb, leading to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. It also causes natriuresis and kaliuresis, but does not match the observed lab profile.

Spironolactone (Option D): Produces mild natriuresis by inhibiting Na+ reabsorption in the cortical collecting tubule, reducing the luminal electronegative gradient. This reduces K+ and H+ secretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis, the opposite of this patient's findings.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics will most likely result in afferent arteriole vasoconstriction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, reducing HCO3- and Na+ reabsorption and increasing delivery of NaCl to the macula densa.

The macula densa senses this elevated NaCl via Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters (NKCC), triggering tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF).

TGF causes afferent arteriole vasoconstriction and efferent arteriole dilation, thereby reducing GFR to limit further salt loss-this mimics a physiologic feedback mechanism used to autoregulate GFR.

Explanation of Other Options:

Amiloride (Option B): Potassium-sparing diuretic that acts on the collecting duct, inhibits ENaC, and does not significantly influence macula densa or afferent arteriolar tone.

Furosemide (Option C): Inhibits NKCC2 in the thick ascending limb, blunts macula densa sensing, and may cause afferent vasodilation, the opposite effect.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option D): Thiazide diuretic acting on the distal convoluted tubule, increases Na+ excretion but does not significantly trigger TGF-mediated afferent constriction.

questions.text: An investigator has designed a drug that acts on the kidneys to increase the urine flow rate. It is increasing the free water clearance (CH20) without affecting sodium or potassium excretion. This drug most likely blocks which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The net effects of vasopressin are mediated by its interaction with the three types of receptors, V1a, V1b, and V2. V2 receptors are primarily located in the principal cells of the renal collecting duct system, as well as on epithelial cells in the thick ascending limb, and on vascular endothelial cells. The drug in this question is blocking vasopressin type 2 (V2) receptors in the collecting duct, because it is increasing the free water clearance (CH20) without affecting sodium or potassium excretion.
  • Free water clearance compares the osmolarity of the urine with plasma osmolarity; increased free water clearance occurs when very dilute urine is formed. Since vasopressin has little effect on sodium excretion, vasopressin antagonists tend to increase urine flow without increasing sodium excretion.
  • Remember that antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or arginine vasopressin regulates serum osmolarity and blood pressure via the V2 and V1 receptors, respectively. ADH decreases serum osmolarity and increases urine osmolarity via regulation of aquaporin channel transcription in the apical membrane of the principal cells of the distal tubule and collecting ducts, leading to increased water permeability.
  • Tolvaptan, for example, acts by selectively antagonising vasopressin V2 receptors, increasing free water excretion. It is indicated for the treatment of both euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia that is symptomatic and resistant to correction with fluid restriction, including patients with heart failure and SIADH.
  • Vaptans block the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) at renal collecting ducts. They are classified based on their route and receptor specificity:
    • IV: Conivaptan (blocks both V1 and V2 receptors)
    • Oral: Tolvaptan (selective V2 receptor blocker)
    • V1 antagonist: Relcovaptan

questions.text: A 45-year-old man goitre undergoes a thyroidectomy. One week later, he develops carpopedal spasms, muscle and abdominal cramps, and tingling of his lips and hands. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium of 6.2 mg/dL and serum phosphorus of 5.7 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs will most likely improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms highly suggestive of hypoparathyroidism, a condition that occurs most frequently after thyroidectomy or the removal of a parathyroid adenoma. Hypoparathyroidism is a condition of parathyroid hormone (PTH) deficiency leading to decreased calcium levels and other electrolyte abnormalities.
  • Normally, a fall in extracellular fluid ionised calcium concentration leads to stimulation of PTH secretion. When released, PTH enhances active reabsorption of calcium and magnesium from distal tubules and the thick ascending limb in the kidney, enhances the release of calcium from bones and enhances the absorption of calcium in the intestine by increasing the production of activated vitamin D. However, in hypoparathyroidism, PTH levels are greatly reduced, resulting in severe hypocalcemia.
  • There are three principal reasons for low Ca2+in such cases
    • Low PTH reduces renal reabsorption of Ca++but increases reabsorption of phosphate.
    • The resulting high plasma phosphate binds plasma Ca++, so plasma Ca++ decreases.
    • Low PTH causes low production of the active form of vitamin D, so Ca++absorption in the small intestine is decreased.
  • Hypoparathyroidism is characterised by severe hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, resulting in tetany, carpopedal spasms, muscle and abdominal cramps, and tingling of the lips and hands. A positive Chvostek sign (tapping the face in front of the ear elicits tetany) and Trousseau sign (abnormal muscular contractions elicited by applying a blood pressure cuff) will often be noted.
  • Since the blood calcium levels are often very low, either calcium gluconate or vitamin D preparations should be administered to correct the condition. Vitamin D preparations, such as Cholecalciferol, elevate calcium levels and also increase phosphate levels. Another treatment option would be to use the vitamin D3 analogue calcitriol. Calcitriol has a mechanism of action similar to that of cholecalciferol. Ergocalciferol is also used, but has a shorter duration and lower potency than cholecalciferol. Although further elevation of serum phosphate would be undesirable, vitamin D analogues are front-line therapy for hypoparathyroidism; phosphate levels may be addressed with phosphate binders or other measures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bumetanide (Option A): A loop diuretic that promotes calcium and potassium excretion; worsens hypocalcemia.

Levothyroxine (Option C): Replaces thyroid hormone, useful in hypothyroidism, not in managing hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism.

Metolazone (Option D): A thiazide-like diuretic that reduces calcium excretion but is not sufficient as a standalone therapy in severe hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is presented with an acute onset of severe ocular pain and blurred vision that is associated with halos around lights. The painful episode began when he walked into a dark room. Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema of the left eye. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with acute angle-closure glaucoma, a medical emergency characterised by sudden eye pain, halos around lights, decreased vision, and a mid-dilated nonreactive pupil. Common in the elderly, hyperopes, and Asian individuals, it can be triggered by pupillary dilation (e.g., in dark rooms or after anticholinergic drugs).
  • Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is a first-line systemic agent in such cases. It works by decreasing bicarbonate production in the ciliary epithelium, thereby reducing aqueous humour formation and rapidly lowering intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Additional management includes IV mannitol (osmotic diuretic) and topical agents such as timolol, apraclonidine, and pilocarpine. These drugs are used to stabilise IOP while preparing the patient for laser peripheral iridotomy, the definitive treatment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Epinephrine (Option B): Sympathomimetic with mydriatic effect, which can worsen angle closure by further narrowing the anterior chamber angle.

Latanoprost (Option C): A prostaglandin F2α analogue used for chronic open-angle glaucoma; it acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow, but is ineffective in acute angle-closure episodes.

Scopolamine (Option D): A potent anticholinergic that dilates the pupil and can precipitate or exacerbate acute angle-closure glaucoma in predisposed individuals.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman is presented with periorbital oedema, a maculopapular rash on her chest, and a fever of 101°F. She has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Laboratory studies of serum show:
1. Sodium = 139 mEq/L
2. Potassium = 4.8 mEq/L
3. Chloride = 100 mEg/L
4. Bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L
5. BUN =58 mg/dL
6. Creatinine = 3.1 mg/dL
Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria and eosinophils. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with the classic triad of fever, rash, and eosinophiluria along with acute kidney injury (elevated BUN and creatinine), which strongly suggests acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).

AIN is most often caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, especially NSAIDs like ibuprofen, antibiotics (e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfonamides), diuretics (e.g., furosemide, thiazides), and others such as phenytoin, cimetidine, allopurinol, and PPIs.

NSAIDs not only cause hypersensitivity-induced AIN but can also lead to hemodynamically-mediated renal failure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. This impairs renal vasodilation, especially dangerous in volume-depleted states or comorbidities like diabetes, heart failure, cirrhosis, or elderly age, where prostaglandins are vital for maintaining renal perfusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acarbose (Option A): Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor used for postprandial hyperglycemia in diabetes; does not cause nephritis or renal impairment.

Clonidine (Option B): Centrally acting alpha-2 agonist for hypertension; adverse effects include sedation and rebound hypertension, not AIN or AKI.

Diltiazem (Option C): Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker; may cause bradycardia or constipation, but AIN is not a known side effect.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with primary hyperparathyroidism and heart failure is brought in because of progressive difficulty breathing and a weight gain of 2 kg over the past week. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, ales are heard bilaterally on auscultation of the chest, and there is 3+ bilateral pitting oedema of the ankles. Which of the following diuretics is contraindicated for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has a history of primary hyperparathyroidism, characterised by unregulated overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and abnormally elevated serum calcium. The classical manifestations can be remembered as:
  • "Bones" (cortical bone loss), "Stones" (renal stones), "Abdominal groans" (constipation), and "Psychic moans" (depression).
  • Thiazide diuretics, which inhibit the NaCl transporter in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), are known to enhance calcium reabsorption. This occurs due to increased activity of the basolateral Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, which is stimulated as a secondary effect of sodium loss in the DCT.
  • Although thiazides rarely cause significant hypercalcemia in normal individuals, they can exacerbate hypercalcemia in patients with underlying causes such as primary hyperparathyroidism, and are therefore contraindicated in such patients.
  • In contrast, loop diuretics such as furosemide promote calcium excretion and are the first-line agents for volume overload in heart failure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aldosterone antagonists (Option A): Used in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. They help reduce mortality and are potassium-sparing; they do not increase calcium levels.

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Option B): Mild diuretics (e.g., acetazolamide) acting in the proximal tubule, often used in glaucoma or metabolic alkalosis. Do not significantly affect calcium balance.

Loop diuretics (Option C): First-line agents in acute decompensated heart failure. Inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb and promote calcium excretion, making them preferred in hypercalcemia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes in with shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination shows bilateral 2+ pitting oedema of the lower limbs, and faint crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Treatment begins with a drug. A few days later, the man returns to the physician because of muscle weakness. Laboratory studies show:
Arterial PCO2 = 48 mm Hq:
Arterial pH = 7.49:
Plasma HCO3 = 35 mEq/L:
Which of the following is most likely decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The data indicate that the man has developed metabolic alkalosis (increased PCO2, pH). This patient has developed metabolic alkalosis, evidenced by elevated pH, elevated bicarbonate (HCO3-), and compensatory elevation of PCO2 (hypoventilation). This is a classical complication of loop or thiazide diuretic overuse, which are commonly prescribed for congestive heart failure (CHF) with volume overload.

Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) act by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of Henle’s loop. This leads to:

  • ↑ distal sodium delivery
  • ↑ Potassium and hydrogen ion loss in the collecting duct due to compensatory exchange mechanisms
  • Metabolic alkalosis (from hydrogen ion loss)
  • Hypokalemia (from excessive renal potassium loss)

Therefore, the most likely decreased parameter is plasma potassium, which can also explain the patient's muscle weakness (classic symptom of hypokalemia).

Explanation of Other Options:

Plasma angiotensin (Option A): Would be increased due to volume depletion from diuretic-induced natriuresis, triggering RAAS activation.

Potassium excretion (Option C): Would be increased, not decreased, due to elevated distal Na+ delivery and aldosterone activation.

Sodium excretion (Option D): Is increased as the primary effect of loop and thiazide diuretics is to block sodium reabsorption.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought in because of a crush injury. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on the lower abdomen and thighs. Two days later, she developed generalised oedema. Laboratory studies show a rise in creatinine from 1.0 to 4.0 mg/dL. She is aggressively hydrated, but remains oliguric. Which of the following drugs is most likely contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has developed acute kidney injury (AKI), as evidenced by the rise in creatinine and oliguria (<400 mL/day). The underlying cause appears to be rhabdomyolysis secondary to crush injury. In rhabdomyolysis, intracellular contents such as myoglobin, potassium, phosphate, and uric acid are released into circulation, leading to tubular obstruction and direct nephrotoxicity.

A major complication of AKI is hyperkalemia, due to reduced excretion and massive potassium release from injured muscle cells.

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, blocks aldosterone receptors in the distal nephron, leading to sodium excretion and potassium retention. In the setting of AKI, where potassium levels are already high, spironolactone can exacerbate hyperkalemia and provoke life-threatening arrhythmias. Hence, it is contraindicated in this context.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; not commonly used in AKI but does not worsen hyperkalemia.

Furosemide (Option B): Loop diuretic that promotes potassium excretion; may be cautiously used to manage volume overload in oliguric AKI.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option C): Thiazide diuretic; generally ineffective in advanced renal dysfunction but does not cause potassium retention.

choices.text: Inhibits distal convoluted tubule sodium and chloride resorption
Inhibits loop of Henle and proximal and distal convoluted tubule sodium and chloride resorption
Inhibits the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin Il

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes in because of an increase in the size of his breasts over the past two months. He has a longstanding history of hypertension and congestive heart failure. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug most likely responsible for the increase in the size of the breasts in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is experiencing gynecomastia, which is relatively common in men as they age and may be related to the extra-glandular conversion of androgens to estrogen. A variety of pathological and drug-related causes can also promote the development of this condition. Causes of gynecomastia include:
    • Deficient production or action of testosterone
    • Renal failure
    • Increased estrogen production (as a result of various tumours)
    • Liver disease
    • Drug-induced
  • Medications Associated with Gynecomastia Development: (DISCKO)
    • Spironolactone
    • Digoxin
    • Cimetidine
    • Alcohol
    • Ketoconazole
    • Estrogens
    • Omeprazole
    • Calcium-channel blockers
  • Each of the answer choices in this question represents the mechanism of action for five different classes of medications that can be used to treat hypertension and/or heart failure.
  • Spironolactone is a "potassium-sparing" diuretic that acts primarily as a competitive inhibitor of aldosterone receptors in the distal segments [distal convoluted tubule, connecting tubule, and collecting tubule (also known as the collecting duct)]. It is used to treat oedema, hypertension, primary hyperaldosteronism, diuretic-induced hypokalemia and NYHA Class III/IV heart failure, as well as idiopathic hirsutism and acne vulgaris. (Remember, one of the primary functions of aldosterone is to increase sodium reabsorption in principal cells of the kidney, which plays a key role in regulating extracellular volume. Aldosterone helps to regulate plasma potassium. The two primary factors that stimulate aldosterone release are plasma angiotensin II and plasma potassium levels.)
  • Spironolactone may cause gynecomastia by displacing androgen from the androgen receptor and sexual-hormone-binding globulin, and by causing increased metabolic clearance of testosterone and higher estradiol production. None of the other choices has gynecomastia as a side effect. Spironolactone also causes hyperkalemia and acidosis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes with severe pain with tenderness in his first metatarsophalangeal joint. He says that the pain was so bad that it woke him up from sleep. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
Laboratory studies show WBC count is 12 × 103/mL, creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, calcium is 8.6 mg/dL, and uric acid is 9.5 mg/dL.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with acute gouty arthritis (AGA), classically involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint with intense pain and swelling, especially at night. His elevated serum uric acid (9.5 mg/dL) and symptoms point to a gout flare.

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is a common cause of hyperuricemia. It reduces urate excretion by enhancing reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to increased serum uric acid levels and predisposing to gout.

Mnemonic: THe NIce PYRAmid drugs cause gout

  • Thiazides (+ loop diuretics)
  • Niacin
  • Pyrazinamide
  • Aspirin (low dose)

Explanation of Other Options:

Aripiprazole (Option A): Atypical antipsychotic with no known association with hyperuricemia or gout.

Enalapril (Option B): ACE inhibitor; can cause hyperkalemia or dry cough, but does not raise uric acid.

Pravastatin (Option D): Statin used for hyperlipidemia; not associated with uric acid metabolism or gout.
